title: Five Things to Know About the Emmys
text:
Didn’t we already say goodbye to “Game of Thrones”? After its finale last spring, the HBO behemoth is now looming over the Emmy Awards, airing Sunday night on Fox. Despite that and other odds-on nominees, there’s room for surprises in the competition and the awards show itself. Here are five things to keep an eye on at the 71st Emmys.

A Host-less Show

Even before controversy caused Kevin Hart to bail out as host of the Oscars, Emmy organizers decided not to recruit a host this year, producers say, in part because they knew celebrities are increasingly leery of such gigs. Plus, by skipping a monologue and other host-led bits, producers gained more show time to work with. Roughly 21 minutes are allotted to stuff other than the announcing and accepting of awards, 27 of which have to be handed out during the three-hour telecast.

However, the lack of a host doesn’t give winners time to ramble on in their acceptance speeches. As nominees are reminded, “There is a thank-you cam offstage, where they can continue thanking their cat, their dog and their agent,” says executive producer Ian Stewart, whose company Done+Dusted is running this year’s show in tandem with Don Mischer Productions.

Mr. Mischer, a veteran producer of such spectacles, adds, “The two things that make these shows successful are: who wins, and what they say when they get up there. As producers, we have absolutely no control over that.”

Netflix’s ‘When They See Us,’ a dramatization of the story of the five teenagers wrongly imprisoned for a 1989 assault on a jogger in Central Park, is a contender for the limited-series award. Photo: Netflix

Cable Incumbent vs. Streaming Upstart

Comparing the annual Emmy haul by HBO and Netflix is at least one way to keep score of the competition between TV’s old and new guard. Last year, Netflix topped HBO in total nominations, 112 vs. 108, breaking HBO’s 17-year streak as the most-nominated network. Ultimately, the two industry heavyweights tied for the most Emmy wins in 2018.

This year, HBO landed back on top with 137 total nominations, breaking its own record, thanks in large part to a flood of nominations for “Game of Thrones” (more on that below). Netflix came in second with 118 nominations, while NBC was a distant third place with 58 nods.

Though Netflix has proved masterful at awards campaigning, having secured nominations in almost every category, the streamer has so far been denied a crowning win in a series-level category. In recent years, Netflix looked on as direct rivals became the first streamers to win best drama series (Hulu’s “The Handmaid’s Tale”) and best comedy series (Amazon’s “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel ”).

On Sunday Netflix does have a shot at seizing its first top award in the category of limited series (aka miniseries). This award has seesawed between HBO and cable network FX in recent years. Netflix has a strong contender in “When They See Us,” director Ava DuVernay’s dramatization of the story of the five teenagers wrongly imprisoned for a 1989 assault on a jogger in Central Park.

The Dragon in the Room

Though the final season of “Game of Thrones” was divisive, to put it mildly, Emmy voters have been eager to honor the last lap around the track for a series whose scale and success changed the industry.

With 32 total nominations, a record for any series in a single season, the show is expected to win best drama (as it did for its previous two seasons) and also break the record “Game of Thrones” previously set, in 2015, for the most single-year awards for a series.

In addition to an expected farewell tribute during the awards show, settle in for lots of “Game”-related names. The drama categories are stacked with them, including best supporting actress, where four out of six nominees played characters in the fictional kingdom of Westeros: Gwendoline Christie, Lena Headey, Sophie Turner and Maisie Williams.

Tony Hale, Gary Cole and Julia Louis-Dreyfus in ‘Veep,’ which ended this season. Photo: HBO

A Comedy Question Mark

Like its fantastical HBO sibling, “Veep” took its bow this year and has dominated at the Emmys, winning best comedy series for its last three seasons. But that showing pales next to Julia Louis-Dreyfus’s streak. If she gets the award for lead actress in a comedy series on Sunday night, it would be her seventh win for her role in the scathing political satire. That would break her tie with Cloris Leachman as the performer with the most overall acting wins.

Yet “Veep” is facing a field of critical hits: “ Barry ” (HBO), “Fleabag” (Amazon), “Russian Doll” (Netflix), “Schitt’s Creek” (Pop TV), “The Good Place” (NBC) and “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” (Amazon).

The latter, set in the stand-up comedy scene of the 1950s and ’60s, took home the top comedy award last year, and seems to have a head of steam. The show earned six trophies, the most of any comedy series, at last week’s Creative Arts Emmys for categories not featured in the main telecast.

Phoebe Waller-Bridge created and stars in Amazon’s ‘Fleabag,’ which is up for the comedy-series award. Photo: Amazon Studios

Changing of the Guard

The annual focus on winning streaks and Goliath nominees makes it all the more refreshing when awards go to young shows, new faces or overdue veterans. When Henry Winkler won his first Emmy last year, for his supporting role as a self-obsessed acting coach in HBO’s “Barry,” he got a standing ovation and read a speech he said he’d written 43 years previously, when he was known as the Fonz. Producer Don Mischer says that moment caused the energy level in the theater to soar.

This year, keep an eye on British phenom Phoebe Waller-Bridge. She created and starred in the darkly comic character study “Fleabag,” whose second season (on Amazon) has been one of the most critically acclaimed runs of the year. “Fleabag” is up for the comedy-series award, and Ms. Waller-Bridge is nominated for lead actress.

Oh, and she also created the stylish thriller “Killing Eve,” which has multiple nominations, including best drama, and put two cast members into the running for lead actress: Jodie Comer and Sandra Oh. A win for Ms. Oh, an eight-time Emmy nominee, would make her the first actress of Asian descent to take home the top award.

Write to John Jurgensen at john.jurgensen@wsj.com
description: Another farewell to ‘Game of Thrones’ and a close race in comedy are among things to watch for in Sunday’s awards show for television
